newsitem.title: UK: OFGAS chief attacks UK Labour profit share plans.
newsitem.headline: OFGAS chief attacks UK Labour profit share plans.

text.p: Britain's gas industry regulator on Monday attacked an opposition Labour Party suggestion that utility companies which make "excess" profits should be forced to share them with customers.
Director General of Gas Supply Clare Spottiswoode said such a scheme would be likely to prompt companies to disguise profit levels, making the regulatory process more difficult.

In evidence to parliament's Trade and Industry Committee, Spottiswoode noted calls for a modification of the existing system under which gas prices are linked to retail prices under an RPI-x formula by including a profit sharing mechanism.
Spottiswoode did not directly mention the fact that leading Labour figures had suggested that profits above a certain level should be returned in part to customers through lower prices.
But she said that while such an idea was "on the face of it appealing", there were fears that it could harm incentives for firms to reduce costs.
Spottiswoode added: "Profit sharing also introduces serious complications in measuring appropriate profits. Companies subject to such a regime are likely to respond by disguising profit levels."
"This reduces the transparency of the regulatory process and is likely to result in prolonged and detailed arguments between company and regulator," she said. -- London Newsroom +44 171 5427767
